Given that the teachers and curriculum are the same style as for CHNS 110, this course is able to build well on an established knowledge base. This is both a positive and a negative, however -- it makes for efficient learning, but that implies very focused, topical learning. More engagement with Chinese media not created specifically for the course would make the experience a little bit more universal -- I don't feel like my Chinese exists much outside of the Li You Wang Peng universe yet, but I may just be impatient. Also, 120 is more grammar-based whereas 110 focuses a lot on pronunciation, and while this is a logical progression, pronunciation in Chinese must be drilled and drilled and drilled before it becomes natural, and some students forgot a bit of what they'd learned in 110 as the semester went on. The teachers, however, know exactly what an English speaker learning Chinese needs in the context and can answer pretty much any question that is asked, no matter how convoluted.
Weaknesses: no curve which is very hard with chinese natives in the class and a lot of work
